author: J. Brewer

review: For $35 and the fact that i'm a techie (patient and able to diagnose problems and experiment) leaves me as a satisfied "mostly Netflix" customer so far.The device was so easy to install and enter passcode to my WiFi -- that took just minutes.  With the iOS app installed on my iPhone i could kick off a Netflix or YouTube (ah, that fireplace video!) in a jiffy.  HiDef, no freezeups.  Chromecast from the Crome broswer (from Windows, from iMac) was a breeze.But then, on day 3, i would try to cast from YouTube and only get the splash screen and video name during startup.  And then nothing else.  I also had the same problem from iPhone, iPad, and Chromebrowser (youtube embedded embedded caster, not browser tab-cast).I finally found that restoring the device to factory settings and re-initializing put me back on the air.  For how long?So, the device has rough spots, and is begging more apps to embed casting.  But if you are a Netflix adict and don't want to wire up your iPhone through an HDMI adapter wire and cool it off with ice cubes, then this is for you!  Then again, if you have a more-modern HD-TV with built in Netflix, why are you considering this device?

author: Amrish

review: This thing is awesome if you know how to use it! I love this thing! Can stream videos, Pandora, YouTube, and so much more from my phone, tablet, PC, etc. A REALLY good app for your phone, tablets, and computers I would highly recommend is called Plex. It basically creates your own "Home Netflix" and will database all you OWN collection of downloaded music, movies, TV shows, etc you have on a hard drive, ext hard-drive, etc. You can then stream from ANY device, and then stream to your chrome cast. Very cool little toy. My wife hated my "new gadget" until I showed her how to use it to watch HER shows. now she LOVES it. $35, you CANNOT go wrong. I ONLY wish it would power itself. My TV doesn't have a USB, so I couldn't power it from a USB spot, and needed to use the power cable. had hoped this was an "all in one self powering device" but it is not. It MUST get power either from a WALL Socket, OR USB slot. Just so people know.

review: This is a great little product for what it does.  I use it as a "netflix" machine in my bedroom. Allows me to watch netflix on my television and essentially use my phone or tablet as a remote.  Note that its purposes are currently limited, and this is NOT a mirror service like Apple TV.I have not had any crashes so far.  WiFi connectivity works well, even though the device is all the way across my house and through multiple levels.I will note two things I do not like about the Chromecast: (1) the device itself gets pretty warm/hot to the touch; because of this, I unplug it when I am away from it; (2) external power is required (either in the form of USB or wall plug).
